feedback: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems that aren’t listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, contact us, giving details of the issue and any assistive technology you are using.
enforcement:
The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS).
contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS)
If you are in Northern Ireland and are not happy with how we respond to your complaint, you can contact theEqualities Commission for Northern Irelandwhich is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’) in Northern Ireland.
Equalities Commission for Northern Ireland
compliance_status:
Compliance StatusThis website complies with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) version 2.2 AA standard.
Compliance Status
preparation:
This statement was prepared on 24 March 2022. It was last reviewed on 9 May 2025.
This website was last tested on 23 April 2025. The test was carried out by TMP Worldwide (UK) Limited.
Most pages on the site were tested, with a focus on reviewing varied page types and pages that contained elements or content where accessibility issues were previously identified.

feedback:
If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, contact: [provide both details of how to report these issues to your organisation, and contact details for the unit or person responsible for dealing with these reports].
If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read, audio recording or braille, please email the following address:info@windrushcommissioner.independent.gov.uk.
info@windrushcommissioner.independent.gov.uk
We’ll consider your request and get back to you in 5 working days.

Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.2

preparation:
Disproportionate Burden Assessment for ReflowScopeAs of September 2018, accessibility legislation states that public sector websites must publish content in an accessible format.WCAG Success Criteria 1.4.10 stipulates that:Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring scrolling in two dimensions for:Vertical scrolling content at a width equivalent to 320 CSS pixels;Horizontal scrolling content at a height equivalent to 256 CSS pixels.Currently most of our pages are set up in such a way that a two-dimensional layout is required.  Enabling reflow properly would require fixing every page on the system, in every way that it can be configured.Benefits of creating an accessible versionThe benefits of enabling 400% reflow is as follows:Reflow into columns would allow a smoother reading process for users with low vision.BurdenWe've estimated that it would take multiple years of work and require redesigning every screen in the system to enable 400% zoom reflow without horizontal scrolling.Other FactorsAs we replace legacy code, we are ensuring that each new element meets the reflow success criteria.  We will also be implementing some fixes which will improve the reflow situation, such as changing the left hand menu display at higher zoom.AssessmentConsidering the fact that we are continually replacing legacy code with new UI, along with the time that it would take to fix the legacy UI, we have concluded that the work involved would be a poor use of staff time. This represents a disproportionate burden on the organisation.
Disproportionate Burden Assessment for ReflowScopeAs of September 2018, accessibility legislation states that public sector websites must publish content in an accessible format.WCAG Success Criteria 1.4.10 stipulates that:Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring scrolling in two dimensions for:Vertical scrolling content at a width equivalent to 320 CSS pixels;Horizontal scrolling content at a height equivalent to 256 CSS pixels.Currently most of our pages are set up in such a way that a two-dimensional layout is required.  Enabling reflow properly would require fixing every page on the system, in every way that it can be configured.Benefits of creating an accessible versionThe benefits of enabling 400% reflow is as follows:Reflow into columns would allow a smoother reading process for users with low vision.BurdenWe've estimated that it would take multiple years of work and require redesigning every screen in the system to enable 400% zoom reflow without horizontal scrolling.Other FactorsAs we replace legacy code, we are ensuring that each new element meets the reflow success criteria.  We will also be implementing some fixes which will improve the reflow situation, such as changing the left hand menu display at higher zoom.AssessmentConsidering the fact that we are continually replacing legacy code with new UI, along with the time that it would take to fix the legacy UI, we have concluded that the work involved would be a poor use of staff time. This represents a disproportionate burden on the organisation.
non_accessible:
Some forms use a 3rd party dropdown select tool named select2 which is known to cause issues for screen reader users. Notably, some aria roles, states and attributes are missing or used incorrectly. This fails WCAG SC 4.1.2, Name, Role, Value. We have added additional, visually hidden information to help users to navigate these elements.  It's also possible to configure the system to replace most of these components with native <select> elements.  A custom accessible multi select component is also being worked on and it will be possible for configurators to use this by late 2024.PDF tagging is not consistent for all PDFs across the site- for example, the application and print book downloadable PDFs.  Tagging implementation for these PDFs should be fixed by the end of 2024.
Some forms use a 3rd party dropdown select tool named select2 which is known to cause issues for screen reader users. Notably, some aria roles, states and attributes are missing or used incorrectly. This fails WCAG SC 4.1.2, Name, Role, Value. We have added additional, visually hidden information to help users to navigate these elements.  It's also possible to configure the system to replace most of these components with native <select> elements.  A custom accessible multi select component is also being worked on and it will be possible for configurators to use this by late 2024.
PDF tagging is not consistent for all PDFs across the site- for example, the application and print book downloadable PDFs.  Tagging implementation for these PDFs should be fixed by the end of 2024.

Content that's not within the scope of the accessibility regulations

PDFs and other documents


Live video

Disproportionate burden
Due to the complexity of our screens, we are unable to pass WCAG SC: 1.4.10 Reflow.  Most pages involve multiple widgets which incorporate tables, graphs or similar graphic elements where it is not possible to enable the page to reflow to 400% zoom without scrolling.  We are working to ensure that any new part of the system that is created is composed in such a way that it is able to reflow correctly. We consider it a disproportionate burden to fix reflow for the legacy code.
Preparation of this accessibility statementThis statement was prepared on 16 July 2024.This website was last tested in July 2024 against the WCAG 2.2  AA standard.The test was carried out by Oleeo using a range of automated tools.
Preparation of this accessibility statement

issue_text:
Some forms use a 3rd party dropdown select tool named select2 which is known to cause issues for screen reader users. Notably, some aria roles, states and attributes are missing or used incorrectly. This fails WCAG SC 4.1.2, Name, Role, Value. We have added additional, visually hidden information to help users to navigate these elements.  It's also possible to configure the system to replace most of these components with native <select> elements.  A custom accessible multi select component is also being worked on and it will be possible for configurators to use this by late 2024.PDF tagging is not consistent for all PDFs across the site- for example, the application and print book downloadable PDFs.  Tagging implementation for these PDFs should be fixed by the end of 2024.
Some forms use a 3rd party dropdown select tool named select2 which is known to cause issues for screen reader users. Notably, some aria roles, states and attributes are missing or used incorrectly. This fails WCAG SC 4.1.2, Name, Role, Value. We have added additional, visually hidden information to help users to navigate these elements.  It's also possible to configure the system to replace most of these components with native <select> elements.  A custom accessible multi select component is also being worked on and it will be possible for configurators to use this by late 2024.
PDF tagging is not consistent for all PDFs across the site- for example, the application and print book downloadable PDFs.  Tagging implementation for these PDFs should be fixed by the end of 2024.

Content that's not within the scope of the accessibility regulations

PDFs and other documents


Live video

Disproportionate burden
Due to the complexity of our screens, we are unable to pass WCAG SC: 1.4.10 Reflow.  Most pages involve multiple widgets which incorporate tables, graphs or similar graphic elements where it is not possible to enable the page to reflow to 400% zoom without scrolling.  We are working to ensure that any new part of the system that is created is composed in such a way that it is able to reflow correctly. We consider it a disproportionate burden to fix reflow for the legacy code.
Preparation of this accessibility statementThis statement was prepared on 16 July 2024.This website was last tested in July 2024 against the WCAG 2.2  AA standard.The test was carried out by Oleeo using a range of automated tools.
Preparation of this accessibility statement
